body.p: An mdoc document body is divided into sections. The names and ordering of these sections is dictated by convention extending to the first published edition of UNIX. The original forms of these sections are documented in the UNIX Programmer's Manual, First Edition, 1971:

blockquote.p: This manual is divided into seven sections:

Commands are programs intended to be invoked directly by the user, in contradistinction to subroutines, which are intended to be called by the user's programs. Commands generally reside in directory bin (for binary programs).

body.p: These conventional sections haven't changed much over the years, although more sections have been added and several have changed with evolving UNIX operating system conventions. The full set of modern sections, and their order, is as follows.

dl.dd: Name of all documented components and a collective description.
Description of all components. This constitutes the bulk of the manual.
Specific notes on the implementation of a generic (e.g., standardised) component.
Return values, if the components are functions.
Environmental variables affecting the components' operation.
Exit status, if the components are commands.
Error conditions, if a command or device driver.
Error conditions, if a function or library.
Links to other relevant manuals or references.
A brief history of the components.
Security precautions beyond the scope of the components.

body.p: Only the NAME and DESCRIPTION sections are required in the document body, although a SYNOPSIS should appear for most manuals as well. Other sections are commonly found depending on the category. For example, RETURN VALUES is found for most category 3 and 2 manuals; while EXIT STATUS is found for most category 1, 6, and 8 manuals.
